Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest

Neil Young and Crazy Horse Americana
Neil Young is a legendary singer
songwriter in musical adventurer having
performed music and genres ranging from
country music to electronic music folk
rock surf music as well and let's not
forget that just in general he's
released some of the most significant
records in rock music period and was
regarded in the 90s by some to be the
godfather of grunge now when I last ran
into a new meal record it was for a
review of his 2010 album the noise not
really one of my favorites in his
catalog but still one that stands out
because of its unique aesthetic in his
catalogue really it's Neil singing solo
a group of songs both new and old and
his only accompaniment is a distorted
reverb wall of guitar noise just
swirling around his vocals and his chord
progressions and a few years later now
we have a brand-new studio effort here
but it's not just Neil it's not just
Neil
oh it's Neal with Crazy Horse the band
he's recorded and performed with on and
off for years they've been there for a
lot of his studio albums most of his
live albums and a great deal of very
important turning points in his career
like his first commercially successful
record as well as his musical Reza
rection in the 70s and his newfound
relevancy in the 90s too and there now
with this record working with Neil on
this new project this new concept album
that has a pretty simple approach but
some interesting results basically
assemble a group of songs with some kind
of significance in the history of
American music and then reworked them
through these really kind of rough fast
and loose folk rock jams that sound like
they're kind of being played live in the
studio and here and there kind of alter
the chord progressions a bit alter the
melodies a bit maybe even change if the
lyrics or the meaning of the story
subtly and while this is nothing
altogether new a lot of artists have put
together full-length LPS celebrating the
history of American music Neil Young and
Crazy Horse definitely have their own
excitingly weird approach when it comes
to approaching the material on this LP I
mean these guys play these old tiny folk
songs with a lot of swagger a lot of
grit distorted guitars just blaring out
of what sounds like a very kind of small
amplifier that is most likely two times
older than me drums with a lot of room
ambience on them and to kind of take the
edge the rough edge off of Mille and his
band playing and and singing there is a
background chorus consisting I I think
mostly of females singing along some of
these songs and adding you know kind of
smoothness a kind of beauty to this very
rusty presentation they really bring a
modern sadness to the song Clementine
and Neil and his band just kind of
lyrically tell it the way it is and
really bring out the songs dark meaning
which is pretty much a tune about the
death of the lover of the narrator of
the song she died in a drowning accident
and they'll even make sure to work in
the verse toward the end of the track
about getting over her death by kissing
her sister
which is pretty messed up and not
something I remember in the song when it
was taught to me as a child mm-hmm and
even more defining moment as the song Oh
Susanna where Neal and crazy horse
really rocked the song out they bring a
real kind of just swanky groove to the
song and they really change up the

sound just so just dirty like Oh Susanna
because I come from Alabama with my BA
and Jo on my knee the way meal and these
guys play they totally strip it of that
youthful innocence that I'm sure most
people associate with it but I kind of
feel like this album starts to falter a
little bit too early in the game the
song gallows pulled I feel doesn't
really take enough liberties with the
song in terms of just mood it feels
really rigid it doesn't really bring
that much fire I guess and I don't

do feel like they're played a little too
straight for me and this album sort of
loses view of its concept as it does
that especially on the Billy n wheeler
track high-flying bird just kind of
seems like a 60s song thrown in there
for good measure and honestly it kind of
feels like Neal in the band are taking
more away from this tracks Jefferson
Airplane cover than they are the
original however I do feel like
Americana regroups and pulls together
for a good ending for the last few
tracks Neal and Crazy Horse definitely
put together the ballsiest recording of
she's coming around the mountain to ever
be placed on wax but I think the most
genius moment of this album comes on the
final track a cover of god save the
queen' toward the middle of the song
Neal and Crazy Horse exposed the melodic
connection between God Save the Queen
and my country tis of thee basically
pointing at the fact that a song
celebrating the monarchy that America
rebelled against was repurposed into a
patriotic song in the
1800s I don't think you need more proof
than that that ripping things off is at
the very root of American culture
I enjoyed the hell out of this record
because of how well it exposes that dark
underbelly of early American music I
just wish it did it more consistently
